title: Man who bashed Toongabbie grandmother Anita Christanga jailed for eight years
text:
A man who brutally bashed an elderly grandmother within an inch of her life as she slept in her home has been jailed for eight years - but he could walk free in just two and a half.

Anita Christanga, 78, was beaten so badly in her home in Toongabbie, Sydney that she lost consciousness and suffered a series of devastating injuries during the attack in January, 2017.

The beloved scripture teacher died four months later, but a coronial inquiry was unable to prove whether her death was related to her injuries sustained from the attack.

Speaking outside of Parramatta District Court on Friday, her family said there was 'no justice' in Friday's sentencing of her attacker, now aged 21.

Anita Christanga, 78, was beaten so badly in her home in Toongabbie, Sydney that she lost consciousness and suffered a series of devastating injuries (pictured)

'There's no justice, absolutely no justice,' her son, Samuel Christanga told 7 News.

'It sucks.'

'We've got nothing, and he comes out in two and a half years with a life still ahead of him,' he said.

The injuries Ms Christanga suffered were severe and included a broken eye socket, jaw, nose, ribs and bleeding on the brain.

She was so badly beaten that she remained unconscious for nine hours until waking in the morning.

The teenager, who cannot be identified for legal reasons, had broken into her home and stolen her phone before the vicious assault began.

After waking from the violent attack, Ms Christanga drove to a bank in Seven Hills to report her stolen credit card.

The beloved scripture teacher and grandmother (pictured) was beaten so badly she lost consciousness for nine hours

The injuries Ms Christanga suffered were lengthy and included a broken eye socket, jaw, nose, ribs and bleeding on the brain

The police were immediately called after the bank's staff saw the extent of her injuries and she was taken to hospital where she underwent several surgeries.

Her family had previously said in an impact statement that upon returning home the grandmother was left traumatised from the attack.

The accused initially denied the assault but later pleaded guilty to a charge of entering a dwelling with intent to commit an indictable offence, larceny, in circumstances of aggravation and inflicting grievous bodily harm, The Daily Telegraph reported.

'It was unnecessary to inflict injuries of such severity,' Judge Grant.

'Although he entered as a thief, his conduct thereafter was brutal, with callous indifference to his victim,' he said.

'This was brutal, callous behaviour that strikes at the sanctity of the home.'

The accused had a difficult childhood and had smoked ice from the age of 14, the court heard.

The man was sentenced to eight years in jail and must serve a minimum of five years and six months.

He will be eligible for parole in July 2022.
